Suzuki cross-coupling reaction over Pd-Schiff-base anchored mesoporous silica catalyst Soma Das Susmita Bhunia Tanmoy Maity Subratanath Koner ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Jadavpur University, Jadavpur, Kolkata 700 032, India Department of Chemistry, Jadavpur University Jadavpur Kolkata 700 032 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +91 33 2414 6666x2778; fax: +91 33 2414 6414. Graphical abstract A highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst has been synthesized by anchoring of palladium(II) into the Schiff-base modified MCM-41. The catalyst has shown unprecedented high conversion in remarkably short time to complete Suzuki cross-coupling reactions. The reaction methodology is very simple, low cost and non-hazardous which can afford an economically and environmentally viable process. The catalyst can be recycled without any significant loss of activity. A new hybrid catalyst has been prepared by tethering a palladium(II) Schiff-base complex via post-synthesis modification of mesoporous silica, MCM-41. The Schiff-base has been derived from o-vanillin and 3-[(2-aminoethylamino)propyl]trimethoxysilane (ATMS) which is chemically anchored on MCM-41 via silicon alkoxide route. The anchored Schiff-base imposed a stable planar coordination sphere on the central palladium ion. The catalyst has been characterized by elemental analysis, small angle X-ray diffraction, FT-IR, UV–vis, N2 sorption study, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) studies and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) studies. X-ray and TEM measurement showed the mesoporosity of the catalyst. The activity of the catalyst has been assessed in the Suzuki CC cross coupling reaction using various phenyboronic acid in heterogeneous condition. High selectivity for the biaryl products containing both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituents, high turnover, mild reaction conditions and possibility of easy recycle makes the catalyst highly desirable to address the industrial needs and environmental concerns. Keywords Mesoporous silica Suzuki reaction Palladium(II) Schiff-base complex Substituted phenylboronic acid Catalyst recycling 1 Introduction Compounds containing CC linkage have found widespread applications in the synthesis of natural products, agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, and advanced materials [1–3]. Several methods are available in the literature for preparation of biaryls [1,4,5]. Among them the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction has developed into an extremely powerful and general method for the preparation of biaryls [1]. For the Suzuki reactions soluble palladium phosphine complexes are usually used as catalysts [6,7]. However, there are some drawbacks in using Pd-complexes like high cost, poor reusability and metal residue contaminating pharmaceutical products [1,8,9], whereas using heterogeneous Pd-catalysts has great economic and environmental importance as they can be easily separated from the reaction and reused for a number of cycles [10,11]. From this standpoint, development of phosphine-free immobilized palladium catalysts is become challenging and important in the field of organic synthesis [12]. Accordingly solid supports such as carbon structures [13], polymers [14] and mesoporous silica [15], etc., have been employed for preparation of heterogeneous palladium catalysts. In this context mesoporous MCM-41 have been widely used in various fields such as catalysis [16], separation [17] and detection [18] since its invention by the scientists of Mobil Corporation [19]. The performance of this material in catalysis endows the homogeneous systems with attractive features as mentioned above, constitutes a rapidly expanding research area [20,21]. Even though ligand free systems are known [22,23], the ligands which lead to formation of electron-rich metal complexes and improve their stability as a viable strategy to circumvent catalyst deterioration and leaching that are necessary to reach a high degree of efficiency and/or selectivity [24,25]. It is worth mentioning that the choice of ligand for functionalization of mesoporous silica has an important effect on the catalytic activity and stability. Recently, Molnár et al. [26] reported that palladium immobilized on silica modified with methyl or phenyl groups exhibit high activity and selectivity in the Heck reaction. Zhao et al. employed a new and different amine, 3-(2-aminoethylamino)propyl modified Pd-MCM-41 catalyst to catalyze the Suzuki reaction under air using xylene as solvent [27]. Palladium complexes have also been immobilized on monodispersed zeolitic hollow spheres, SBA-16 and/or KIT-6 to catalyze Suzuki-Miyaura reaction [28–30]. In the course of our continuing investigation in synthesis of heterogeneous catalyst using modified mesoporous MCM-41, we have attempted palladium immobilization on MCM-41 which efficiently catalyzes various CC cross coupling reactions [31,32]. Further exploration in this area allows us to derive a new heterogeneous system that is highly active toward Suzuki coupling reaction in entirely phosphine-free and leaching free condition. The catalyst is recoverable and reusable and requires markedly short time to complete Suzuki cross-coupling reactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials PdCl2 (>99.9%), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98%), the cationic surfactant cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 98%), 3-[(2-aminoethylamino)propyl]-trimethoxysilane (ATMS), 3-mercaptopropyl-functionalized silica (SH-SiO2) [sulfur content of SH-SiO2 =3.95wt%], and all other reagents were purchased either from Sigma–Aldrich/Fluka or Alfa-Aesar and were used as received without further purification. Solvents were purchased from Merck (India) and were distilled and dried before use. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of MCM-41 The pure siliceous MCM-41 was prepared according to the literature method [33] by using hydrothermal crystallization process. The sample was prepared from a gel composition of 1.0 CTAB:10.0 TEOS:3.0 NaOH:600 H2O. A typical synthesis gel was prepared by adding 5.78g of TEOS slowly dropwise to an aqueous solution containing 1.01g of CTAB and 0.34g of NaOH and 30mL of distilled water under stirring condition. After further stirring for about 1h at room temperature, the resulting homogeneous mixture was then transferred to a Teflon lined autoclave and aged under static hydrothermal conditions at 383K for 96h. The solid product was obtained by suction filtration, washed with deionized water, dried in air at 373K and calcined in air at 813K for 6h to remove the occluded CTAB. This as-synthesized material was referred to as M-41. 2.2.2 Inclusion of amine groups into M-41 In a typical experiment [Scheme 1(a)], 0.1g M-41 (without template), 12mL dry toluene, and 1.0mL (0.46mmol) 3-[(2-aminoethylamino)propyl]trimethoxysilane (ATMS) were placed in a 25mL two necked round bottom flask. The mixture was stirred at 363K for 12h under the protection of N2 atmosphere by using Schlenk apparatus. The white solid thus formed, named M(A1)-41, was filtered, washed with toluene for several times followed by dichloromethane and dried in air. 2.2.3 Generation of Schiff-base in M(A1)-41 The preparation was carried out by using o-vanillin (0.7g, 4.6mmol) in 10mL methanol and 0.1gM(A1)-41 as shown in Scheme 1(b). The mixture was then stirred in room temperature for half an hour and then placed in an oil bath in refluxing condition at 65°C for 6h under air. A yellow colored compound was formed which was filtered, washed with methanol and dried in desiccator. The final products were denoted as M(SB1)-41. 2.2.4 Preparation of catalyst M(P1)-41 In a 25mL round bottom flask, the above-functionalized material, M(SB1)-41 was mixed with 0.01g (0.057mmol) PdCl2 in 20mL dry acetone [Scheme 1(c)]. The mixture was refluxed at 56°C for 72h under air. The resulting solution was filtered off and the dirty yellow colored solid was washed several times with acetone. After filtration, the product was dried and then soxhlet extracted with acetone for 12h until all physisorbed complexes were removed from the surfaces and dried under vacuum. The catalyst thus obtained is designated as M(P1)-41. The Pd content of the catalyst found to be 1.2 (wt.%) (1.13×10−2 mol.%). Elemental analysis showed Pd:C and Pd:N were 12.55 and 1.77, respectively. 2.3 Characterization Mesoporous materials were characterized by small angle powdered X-ray (SAX) diffraction study. The SAX patterns of all powdered samples were taken in the 2θ range of 2–10° at a rate of 2°min−1 in steps of 0.02° (Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer) using Cu-Kα radiation. IR spectra were measured on a Perkin-Elmer RX I FT-IR spectrometer. The solid state UV–vis spectra were recorded by a Cary 5000 UV–vis-NIR spectrophotometer in the wavelength range of 200–800nm. Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer was used to collect microanalytical data (C, H and N). The palladium content of catalyst was determined by a Perkin Elmer A-Analyst 200 atomic absorption spectrometer (AAS). The BET surface area and total pore volume of the mesoporous samples were determined by an Autosorb-iQ (Quantachorme Inc.) gas sorption system. Prior to analyses, all the samples were degassed at 130°C under vacuum until a final pressure of 10−2 Torr was reached to evacuate the physically adsorbed moisture. The transmission electron micrograph (TEM) of samples was obtained by JEOL-TEM-2010 electron microscopes with an acceleration voltage of 200kV. Field emission scanning electron microscopic (FESEM) image and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis of samples (with gold coating) was recorded on INSPECT F50, FEI, The Netherland. TG/DTA thermograms were recorded on a Perkin Elmer (Singapore) Pyris Diamond TG/DTA unit with N2 carrier gas flowing at a rate of 150mLmin−1 and the heating rate was programmed at 4°Cmin−1. All products of the catalytic reactions were collected and purified by either crystallization or column chromatographic method and characterized by elemental analysis (using Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer) and comparison of their NMR spectra with those reported in the literature. Reactions were monitored by TLC and a Varian CP-3800 gas chromatograph using a CP-Sil 8 CB packed column. Unless otherwise noted, 1H spectra were recorded in CDCl3 or in DMSO-d6 on a Bruker Avance DPX 300 NMR (300MHz) spectrometer. 2.4 General procedure for Suzuki reaction Coupling reactions were carried out in a 25mL round bottom flask under refluxing condition in air. At first aryl halide (1.0mmol) and phenylboronic acid (1.5mmol) were dissolved in 4mL ethanol. To this reactant mixture 1mL of aqueous solution of K2CO3 (0.276g, 2mmol) was added under stirring conditions at 60°C in an oil bath. Then 0.005g of M(P1)-41 catalyst was added to it and the progress of reaction was monitored by GC at regular intervals. At the end of the catalytic reaction, the catalyst was first separated out by centrifugation and then the filtrate was extracted four times with ethanol (4×15mL). The filtrate thus collected were combined and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. Products are purified by crystallization and column chromatography over silica gel (mesh 60–120) using a hexane/ethyl acetate mixture as the eluent to give the desired product. The product was analyzed by GC and/or 1H NMR. All of the products were known. The spectroscopic data (1H NMR) of these products are consistent with those of reported values. 2.5 Results and discussion 2.5.1 X-ray diffraction studies Small angle X-ray diffraction patterns of M-41, M(A1)-41 and M(P1)-41 are shown in Fig. 1 . The patterns of fresh M-41 demonstrate the mesostructure, i.e. a typical three-peak pattern [19,34] with a very strong d 100 =35.30Å diffraction peak at 2θ ≈2.50Å and two small diffraction peaks for the 110 and 200 planes at 2θ ≈4.29Å and 2θ ≈4.96Å, respectively, confirming a well defined hexagonal symmetry and long-range ordering of structure. Like the parent material M-41, both M(A1)-41 and M(P1)-41 shows the similar diffraction lines indicating the chemical process involved in modification of mesoporous silica did not diminish the structural ordering of the M-41 although some degree of decrease in crystallinity takes place in the catalyst. A successive decrease in the intensity and shifting of the peaks toward the higher angle is observed after the sequential modification of the pore of M-41. This is probably due to the lowering of local order, such as variations in the wall thickness, or it may be due to the reduction of scattering contrast among the channel wall of the silicate framework, Schiff-base ligand and palladium complex present in catalyst mentioned previously by Lim and Stein [35]. 2.5.2 IR spectra Fig. 2 shows the FTIR spectra of M-41, M(A1)-41 and M(P1)-41. IR spectrum of M-41 exhibits a broad band at 1647cm−1 due to OH bending vibration. Various CH and NH vibration bands appeared in the region 3100–2800cm−1 and 1650–1450cm−1 in the IR spectrum of amine modified moiety, M(A1)-41 and these bands were absent in that of M-41 which clearly indicates the anchoring of ATMS into the M-41 matrix. Interestingly, after o-vanillin treatment one change in the spectra has been noticed, the OH band of water at 1631cm−1 merges with a new broad band centered at 1654cm−1 attributable to the CN stretching frequency of generated Schiff-base into the porous material by condensation between amine group of ATMS and carbonyl group of o-vanillin. Thus it is evident that the aldehyde groups are converted into Schiff-base and indicate to form Pd complex. 2.5.3 Electronic spectra In order to get an insight into the coordination environment around Pd(II) center in the solid matrix, UV–vis spectroscopic measurements were performed. The solid-state electronic spectra of M(A1)-41, M(SB1)-41 and M(P1)-41 are shown in Fig. 3 . All the samples show an intense peak around 200nm which is typical of siliceous materials [36]. Schiff-base modified MCM-41 showed a band around 416nm which could be attributed to intra-ligand charge transfer transition of azomethine chromophore. A shifting of intra-ligand charge transfer band was observed upon complexation of Pd(II) with Schiff-base ligand in catalyst M(P1)-41. The blue shift of the band from 416nm to 392nm in catalyst indicates coordination interaction between PdCl2 and Schiff-base ligand in catalyst [37]. 2.5.4 N2 sorption study The N2 sorption isotherms and pore size distribution plots for M-41, M(A1)-41 and M(P1)-41 are displayed in Fig. 4A and B, respectively. All the isotherms exhibit a type IV isotherm (according to the IUPAC nomenclature), with hysteresis loops, characteristic of the mesoporous materials. A noticeable decrease in BET surface area, pore volume and pore diameter was observed at the stage of amine modification which is consistent with the fact that a much bulky organic fragments entered into the channels. The nitrogen sorption study exhibits that the BET surface area of M-41 is 1379m2 g−1 and the mesopore volume is 0.73cm3 g−1. The average pore diameter is calculated to be 23.1Å using the NLDFT method. All calculated values are in agreement with those reported for good quality MCM-41. On the other hand M(A1)-41 shows lower N2 uptake (BET surface area 344m2 g−1) and pore volume 0.21cm3 g−1 and pore diameter 15.4Å. Whereas the catalyst M(P1)-41 shows further lower N2 uptake (BET surface area 208m2 g−1) and pore volume 0.14cm3 g−1 and pore diameter 14.2Å which is clearly suggest that the metal complexes are occupying the pores. This kind of reduction in surface area, pore volume and pore diameter was also observed for similarly prepared mesoporous catalyst using a less bulky amine (APTES) by Dhara et al. [38] and Ma et al. [39]. Change in surface area as well as pore volume between M(A1)-41 and M(P1)-41 was smaller than between M-41 and M(A1)-41. It seems space occupied by the amine moiety has not changed substantially after complex formation with palladium. 2.5.5 TEM study To assess the mesoporosity of M-41 and catalyst, M(P1)-41, the samples were studied with high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). In Fig. 5(a), M-41 sample viewed along the pore axis reveals an open-ended lamellar type arrangement of hexagonal porous tubules. These channels or stripes can be interpreted as images of nanopores aligned perpendicular to the electron beam. In Fig. 5(b), HRTEM of M-41 is shown in the perpendicular direction of the pore axis. The 2D-hexagonal arrangement of the pores with a different contrast than that of the pore walls throughout the specimen is quite clear. M(P1)-41 sample also exhibits a similar type of array of regular rows and hexagonal arrangement in TEM micrographs shown in Fig. 5(c) and (d), respectively. Therefore, it can be concluded that both the samples have a similar type of external morphology, i.e. ordered mesoporous silica based matrix remains almost intact throughout all the reaction steps starting from the surface functionalization to the binding of Pd(II). 2.5.6 FESEM/EDX studies Field emission-scanning electron micrographs of both M-41 and M(P1)-41 were taken and those images support the conclusion that no significant changes in the surface morphology occurred upon inclusion of Pd on M-41 (see supplementary material, Fig. S1) though some sort of roughening of the surface takes place. The EDX elemental analysis indicated the presence of palladium and chloride in catalyst whereas those atoms are absent in M-41 (see supplementary material, Fig. S2). The ratio of Pd:Cl obtained from EDX was close to 1:1 ratio. This ratio signifies that palladium atoms in the catalyst may be four coordinated, two nitrogen and one oxygen atoms from the Schiff-base ligands and other coordination site was filled by one chloride atoms. 2.5.7 Thermal measurements Thermogravimetric analysis of the M(P1)-41 catalyst was performed using the powder sample under nitrogen atmosphere. TG curve as shown in Fig. 6 indicates that upon heating, M(P1)-41 showed a weight loss of about 2.5wt.% between room temperature and 100°C. Corresponding DTA curve shows a broad and weak endothermic peak in the above temperature range. Thereafter, the TG curve remains flat up to ∼265°C, indicating no mass loss in this temperature range. Upon further heating, the TG curve shows a mass loss, about 15%, in the temperature range from 265 to 568°C, which corresponds to a broad and weak endothermic peak centered at ∼527°C in its DTA curve. A third slight mass loss in TG curve of about 4.5%, is also found in the temperature range from 731 to 800°C, which corresponds to a sharp endothermic peak centered at ∼764°C in its DTA curve. The first mass loss seems to be due to removal of adsorbed water and solvent molecules, while the second mass loss may be due to decomposition of the organically modified framework. The loss centered at higher temperature should be attributed to desorption of several organic species. The third stage, above 500°C may related to the water loss caused the weight loss also, as a result of the condensation of the silanol groups. 2.5.8 Catalytic activity studies To illustrate the catalytic activity of M(P1)-41 in the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction, we first tested the reaction between bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid, and the results are summarized in Table 1 . Previous studies have showed that influences of different parameters had remarkable effect on the reactivity of the Suzuki reaction [23,32]. The parameters included reaction environment, solvent, base, reaction temperature, % Pd loading in catalyst and the reaction period. Thus we examine those parameters for Suzuki coupling reaction (as mentioned above) to find out the best suitable reaction conditions. The catalyst M(P1)-41 is not thermal, air, or moisture sensitive, and hence inert atmosphere was not employed. Now we focused on the effect of solvents and the results of investigations are shown in Table 1. Preliminary screening of the solvent revealed that the presence of DMF could efficiently catalyze the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction in water (Table 1, entry 2); however, palladium leached out from the solid catalyst, which is not desirable for heterogeneous catalysts. Leaching of palladium was diminished by an increasing H2O/DMF ratio while some sort of decrease in reactivity was also observed (Table 1, entries 3 and 4). It is well-established that leaching of Pd often occurs in a CC coupling reaction, if DMF is used as a solvent [40]. Notably desirable activity of the catalyst M(P1)-41 was achieved by using ethanol instead of DMF. Using ethanol only as solvent we obtained a respectable amount of product (Table 1, entry 7), while in case of H2O, poor yield was obtained (Table 1, entry 5). However, we find that the reaction occurred instantaneously in 20% aqueous ethanol (Table 1, entries 8 and 13). The merit of the co-solvent was attributed to the good solubility of the organic reactants and the inorganic base [39]. To find out the suitable base in this catalytic reaction using our catalyst we have undertaken a series of reactions with different bases. Under the same conditions KHCO3, NaHCO3, NaOAc·3H2O, KOAc, Na3PO4·12H2O, and K3PO4·3H3O gave moderate biphenyl yields (Table 1, entries 14–19). Remarkably, when Na2CO3 and K2CO3 were used (Table 1, entries 13 and 8), good to excellent biphenyl yields were obtained. The use of trialkylamine or lithium chloride as bases resulted in low yield (Table 1, entries 20 and 21). Indeed, K2CO3 in 20% aqueous ethanol was found to be the best choice in view of an almost quantitative biphenyl yield obtained within a short reaction time (50min) (Table 1, entry 8). Besides, we found that the coupling reaction yields were susceptible to temperature changes in the presence of catalyst and aqueous ethanol as solvent along with base (Table 1, entries 8, 11 and 12). At room temperature a very slow progress of reaction was observed and the yield was found <30%, whereas the increase of reaction temperature up to 60°C led to excellent yields (100%). To optimize the catalytic efficacy of M(P1)-41, we controlled the immobilization of palladium by varying the amount of PdCl2 in the Schiff-base complex formation as shown in Fig. S3 (see supplementary material). With the above mentioned reaction condition, we investigated the catalytic activity of M(P1)-41 for various substrates and the results are summarized in Table 2 . Firstly we found that bromobenzene (Table 2, entry 2) showed quantitative yields within 50min which leads us to attempt with the other Suzuki coupling reactions using nonsubstituted aryl halides. Among nonsubstituted aryl halides, iodobenzene required little longer time (60min) (Table 2, entry 3) in comparison to that of bromobenzene for full conversion. Iodobenzene generally shows greater reactivity than bromobenzene in the cross-coupling reactions. Nevertheless, there were some exceptions where reverse catalytic activity was observed in palladium nanoparticle-based catalysts [41,42]. In a recent study, it had been proposed that the Ī or I2 generated from iodobenzene can act as an inhibitor during the catalytic process [41,42]. The M(P1)-41 catalyst was also capable of activating chlorobenzene (Table 2, entry 1) which normally remains unreactive in CC coupling reaction due to strong CCl bond [43,44]; however, the yield was much lower and required much longer time (1440min) than that of bromobenzene for 85% conversion. Encouraged by so high an activity of the developed catalyst, we decided to explore the potential of the catalyst for substituted reactants. For substituted bromobenzene bearing NO2, COCH3, OCH3, OH, NH2 groups also afforded enhanced activity in Suzuki reactions (Table 2, entries 6–12). It is worth noting here that the TOF reached ca. 5310h−1 in the case of p-nitrobromobenzene which completes the reaction in 20min. However, aryl bromides containing the m-NO2 and o-NO2 group showed only little inertness to complete the reaction, probably due to electronic and steric hindrance, but TOFs still exceeded 4991h−1 and 4566h−1 (Table 2, entries 7 and 8), respectively. It is noticeable here that the deactivated aryl halides like p-hydroxybromobenzene, p-aminobromobenzene also showed moderate conversion and yield within 140min (Table 2, entries 11 and 12), though it is obvious that the reactivity of aryl bromides with electron-withdrawing substituents (Table 2, entries 6–9) will usually be higher than that of electron-donating substituents (Table 2, entries 10–12). We further tested the catalytic performances for the couplings of various arylboronic acids with bromobenzene (Table 2, entries 4 and 5). For arylboronic acids bearing electron-donating group OCH3 and electron-withdrawing groups COCH3, 98% and 85% yields were obtained in 25min and 60min (Table 2, entries 4 and 5), respectively when reacts with bromobenzene. As p-methoxyphenylboronic acid gave excellent yield in much shorter time than phenylboronic acid, we performed the coupling reactions for all substituted bromobenzene (as in case of phenylboronic acid) with p-methoxyphenylboronic acid. The electronic factor is also important for these reactions. In case of p-nitrobromobenzene 100% conversion and almost quantitative yield was obtained in 15min with 7079h−1 TOF (Table 2, entry 13). Table 2, entries 13–19 manifests the same trends of activity as for phenylboronic acid which suggests the controllers of these coupling reactions with substituted reactants are the electronic and steric factor. 2.5.9 Catalyst integrity and leaching An objective of our studies is to determine whether the catalysis is due to the M(P1)-41 or to a homogeneous palladium complex that comes off the support during the reaction and then returns to the support at the end. To elucidate this matter, we performed a series of tests as described below. 2.5.9.1 Hot filtration test To test if metal was leaching out from the solid catalyst during reaction, hot filtration test was done [45]. A mixture of bromobenzene (0.157g, 1mmol), phenylboronic acid (0.183g, 1.5mmol), K2CO3 (0.276g, 2mmol), M(P1)-41 (0.005g) in 5mL of 20% H2O/EtOH was stirred at 60°C and the progress of the reaction was monitored by GC analysis. The reaction mixture was filtered (Whatman 1, pore size 11μm) at the reaction temperature when the catalytic reaction was 60% complete (analyzed by GC) and the residual activity of the filtrate was further studied keeping the same reaction condition. The catalyst filtration was performed at the reaction temperature in order to avoid possible re-coordination or precipitation of soluble palladium upon cooling. We found that, after this hot filtration, the filtrate did not exhibit any catalytic activity, i.e. there was no progress of reaction (see supplementary material, Fig. S4). Besides, AAS analysis (sensitivity up to 0.001ppm) of the supernatant solution of the reaction mixture confirmed the absence of palladium ions in the liquid phase justifying the prepared catalyst was indeed catalyzing the cross-coupling reaction heterogeneously. 2.5.9.2 Solid-phase poisoning test According to Richardson and Jones, solid-phase poisoning test is one of the important tests to ascertain the true heterogeneity of the Pd based catalyst [46]. To perform this test, a mixture of SH-SiO2 (0.05g, 0.06mmol) and 0.005g of M(P1)-41 catalyst were taken in the solution containing bromobenzene (0.157g, 1mmol), phenylboronic acid (0.183g, 1.5mmol) and K2CO3 (0.276g, 2mmol) in 5mL of 20% H2O/EtOH. The mixture was stirred continuously maintaining the temperature of the oil bath at 60°C. The progress of the reactions was monitored by the method described above. In this test, metal free mercaptopropyl-functionalized silica (in our case SH-SiO2) was used as an effective palladium scavenger that selectively coordinates and deactivates the leached out palladium [46]. Thereby, cessation of the reaction is expected, if the coupling reaction was catalyzed by leached palladium species from the solid support. A comparison of percentage of conversion in the absence and presence of solid poison in CC coupling reactions (see supplementary material, Fig. S5) clearly indicates that the catalytic activity of M(P1)-41 was not affected even in the presence of poisoning agent SH-SiO2. Notably, there was no induction period in these reactions in the presence or absence of the poisoning agent. 2.5.9.3 Three phase test As a definite examination of the heterogeneous/homogeneous question, we performed a three-phase test [45,47] for Suzuki reaction using a designed aryl halide in usual condition as described in Scheme S1 (see supplementary material). To perform this test, we chose aryl halide (in this case p-bromoanisole), PBA-MCM-41 in which p-bromoacetophenone (PBA) is anchored on the surface of the ATMS functionalized MCM-41 as shown in Scheme 2 . A solution of p-bromoanisole (0.187g, 1mmol), phenylboronic acid (0.183g, 1.5mmol), and K2CO3 (0.276g, 2mmol) in 5mL 20% H2O/EtOH was stirred in the presence of 0.005g of M(P1)-41 and 1g of PBA-MCM-41 at 60°C for 1h. The reaction mixture was collected by filtration and workup in the usual manner, while the residual portion was hydrolyzed with 2N aqueous HCl solution (1.7mL HCl in 8.5mL H2O) for 3h under a refluxing condition and isolated as p-bromoacetophenone. Both the resulting solution was analyzed by GC and 1H NMR. In the case of the immobilized aryl bromide, no reaction was observed on support even after 2h at 60°C and we found unreacted p-bromoacetophenone in 98% yield, while the soluble p-bromoanisole substrate converted to p-methoxybiphenyl in 95% yield as expected for Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reaction, indicating the presence of an active catalyst and demonstrating the coupling reactions were performed heterogeneously by our catalyst. Therefore, all the above tests convincingly demonstrate that there was no noticeable leaching of Pd species occurring in the M(P1)-41 catalyzed CC coupling reactions. 2.5.10 Recycling of the catalyst As we have mentioned previously that the catalyst M(P1)-41 is not thermal, air, or moisture sensitive and the reaction is carried out in mild reaction condition under air, so we decided to check the recyclability of our Pd(II)-catalyst in the model Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction using bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid maintaining the same reaction condition. As 5mg of solid catalyst is not enough to recover, reuse and finally characterize, therefore the catalyst was collected from different batches of same catalytic cycle and an average value of data are given here. After the first cycle of the reaction, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation and washed thoroughly with diethyl ether, followed by copious amount of water to remove the base present in the used catalyst and finally by dichloromethane. The recovered catalyst was dried under vacuum at 100°C overnight. Atomic absorption spectrometric analysis of the recovered catalysts confirmed the palladium content of the M(P1)-41 remained virtually the same, even after its reuse. The recovered catalyst was then subjected to X-ray powder diffraction study and IR spectral analysis. Comparison of X-ray diffraction patterns (see supplementary material, Fig. S6) and IR spectra (see supplementary material, Fig. S7) of the pristine compound and recovered catalyst convincingly demonstrates the structural integrity of the compound retained after the reactions. This used catalyst was re-employed in five successive cycles under identical conditions. The performance of the recycled catalyst in all cycles is shown in Fig. 7 , respectively. It is found that the catalyst can be reused several times without any significant loss of yield and catalytic activity. In search of efficient heterogeneous catalysts for the Suzuki coupling reactions, attempts have been made, of which a few deserve particular mention. This reaction catalyzed by various palladium containing heterogeneous catalysts is given in Table 3 . Corma et al. reported the Suzuki coupling of p-bromoanisole by a Pd-containing MOF in an ethanol medium at 25°C, which yields p-methoxybiphenyl with high selectivity, but it requires a longer time period (48h) for a conversion of 87% [48]. Štěpnička et al. studied the Suzuki coupling reaction of substituted bromobenzene by the reusable Pd-catalyst prepared from mesoporous molecular sieves bearing nitrogen donor groups with different palladium loading, and in some cases quantitative yield was obtained in anhydrous ethanol medium after 24h of reaction [49]. Palladium nanoparticles embedded in a porous sponge like silica were used as a catalyst in the Suzuki coupling reaction of p-bromoanisole and phenylboronic acid, and up to a 96% yield was obtained at a higher temperature (135°C) in the DMF medium. However, in this case, a gradual decrease in catalytic activity was observed in subsequent cycles [47]. Štěpnička et al. reported Suzuki coupling of p-bromotoluene in the ethanol/water medium catalyzed by a palladium complex of phosphinoferrocenyl carboxamides bearing glycine pendant groups in homogeneous conditions with high yield and selectivity [50]. Corma et al. observed Pd-leaching in the Suzuki coupling reaction catalyzed by Pd-containing basic zeolites in ethanol–water/ethanol medium, and toluene was used as a solvent to avoid metal leaching [51]. In our previous report we found a similar type of palladium catalyst system using APTES as amine functionalization, able to catalyze Suzuki cross-coupling reaction in a very green way and also showed high yield and selectivity for biaryl products [32]. But it takes longer reaction time in comparison to our present catalyst system. Zhao et al. performed the reaction using xylene as solvent which gives 95% yield of p-acetylbiphenyl in 6h where the catalyst was modified with the same amine as we did [27]. However, catalyst M(P1)-41 demonstrates a high efficiency in all the reactions in terms of yield, cost, reaction time, reaction condition, turn over frequency, and reusability. 3 Conclusion In summary, by incorporating the Pd(II)-complex in the post-synthetically modified interior pores of MCM-41, a new and non-phosphine solid palladium catalyst, M(P1)-41, was successfully prepared which afforded fast conversions for the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions of various aryl halides and arylboronic acids in aqueous ethanol at a catalyst loadings of 0.0113mol%. The catalytic system tolerates a broad range of functional groups and gives high to moderate yields even with the deactivated systems in a short period of time. Thus the developed solid catalyst represents one of the most efficient heterogeneous systems for the Suzuki reaction of aryl bromides suggesting potential application of this catalyst in the synthesis of a large variety of targeted organic molecules. Moreover, the encapsulated Pd shows outstanding stability, no significant leaching and reusability at least 5 times without any significant decrease in activity which make the catalyst cheap and highly desirable to address the environmental concerns. coredata.dc:description: A new hybrid catalyst has been prepared by tethering a palladium(II) Schiff-base complex via post-synthesis modification of mesoporous silica, MCM-41. The Schiff-base has been derived from o-vanillin and 3-[(2-aminoethylamino)propyl]trimethoxysilane (ATMS) which is chemically anchored on MCM-41 via silicon alkoxide route. The anchored Schiff-base imposed a stable planar coordination sphere on the central palladium ion. The catalyst has been characterized by elemental analysis, small angle X-ray diffraction, FT-IR, UV–vis, N2 sorption study, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) studies and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) studies. X-ray and TEM measurement showed the mesoporosity of the catalyst. The activity of the catalyst has been assessed in the Suzuki CC cross coupling reaction using various phenyboronic acid in heterogeneous condition. High selectivity for the biaryl products containing both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituents, high turnover, mild reaction conditions and possibility of easy recycle makes the catalyst highly desirable to address the industrial needs and environmental concerns.
coredata.dc:title: Suzuki cross-coupling reaction over Pd-Schiff-base anchored mesoporous silica catalyst
